awd_titl_txt: RUI:   Mathematical Analysis of Several Models in Nonlinear Optics
awd_abstract_narration:
The most recent advances in nonlinear optics include the generation and applications of ultrashort optical pulses, whose time duration is typically of the order of femtoseconds (one quadrillionth of a second). Duration of these pulses is approaching the timescales of fundamental atomic and molecular processes. They deliver energy so quickly that it allows them to probe living structures without damage and to make material modifications on the micron scale with minimal heat effects. Femtoscale lasers are used, for example, in microsurgery or materials processing. For ultrashort pulses, the traditional mathematical models used for longer optical pulses, the Nonlinear Schrödinger (NLS) and Coupled Nonlinear Schrödinger (CNLS) equations, lose their predictive capabilities. This research project is concerned with two novel mathematical models: the Complex Short Pulse (CSP) equation and the Coupled Complex Short Pulse (CCSP) equation. The project is devoted to analysis and computation of solutions of these equations for the description of ultrashort optical pulses.

The models to be investigated are integrable; the project concerns the investigation of the CSP equation, the CCSP equation and their integrable semi-discrete analogues, where the spatial variable takes values in a lattice, while the integrability of the resulting equations is preserved.  In particular, the investigator plans to: (1) construct the semi-discrete CSP equation and derive exact solutions including bright and dark solitons and rogue-wave-like solutions; (2) construct bright-bright, dark-dark and bright-dark (mixed) soliton solutions, as well as rogue wave solutions, of the CCSP equation; (3) utilize the semi-discrete CSP equation as a novel self-adaptive moving mesh numerical method for simulating solutions of the continuous CSP model. Being at the second largest Hispanic-serving institution in the country, the investigator strives to motivate and encourage undergraduate and graduate students to engage in cutting-edge research in applied mathematics.

por.por_cntn:
This project concerns the investigation of several newly proposed models for describing the proppagation of ultra-short pulses in nonlinear optics, which include the complex short pulse (CSP) equation and coupled complex short pulse (CCSP) equation and their integrable semi-discrete analogues. These models can be viewed as analogues, in ultra-short pulse regime, of the nonlinear Schrodinger (NLS) equation, coupled nonlinear Schrodinger (CNLS) equation and Ablowitz- Ladik (AL) lattice and coupled AL lattice equations.

In this project, the inverse scattering transform (IST) and Darboux transformation were developed for the complex short pulse (CSP)  and coupled complex short pulse (cCSP) equations. With his collabortors, the PI advanced a so-called Kadomtsev-Petviashvili (KP)-Toda reduction method developed from the marriage of Hirota's bilinear method and KP theory by Kyoto School. Solution formulas of solitons such as breather and rogue waves for several integrable equations including the Yajima-Oikawa equation, the generalized derivative NLS equation, the complex short pulse equation, the Sasa-Satsuma equation, the massive-Thirring model.  The rogue wave patterns were analyzed and it is found to be  connected with the root structure of Wronskian-Hermite orthogonal polynomials. The PI also studied the NLS equation, the AL equation and the semi-discrete CSP equation by Darboux transformation and constructed their various soliton solutions including rogue waves. A systematic method: the KP-Toda reduction method, proposed in this project of finding various solutions including dark, breather and rogue wave solutions under nonzero boundary conditions will quickly provide us with the solutions of many inegrable nonlinear wave equations  so that applied mathematicians and physicists can further study their dynamical properties and potential applications.

The PI has been working on integrable discretization of soliton equations. During the project period, by connecting the discrete KP equation with soliton equations, the PI derived an integrable semi-discrete modified Camassa-Holm equation, constructed the rogue wave solutions to  the fully discrete NLS equation.

During the project period, three Master's theses were produced and nine undergraduate's research projects were conducted.  Among three graduate students, one was accepted by the Ph.D. program at the Southern Methodist University and one was accepted by the new Ph. D. program at UTRGV. Among nine undergraduate students, two students enrolled in the graduate program at UTRGV and obtained their Master's degrees.
